Situation1: They remain cheerful and patient while handling an upset customer during a peak holiday rush.
Expectation2: Respect the privacy and confidentiality of the people you are helping
Situation2: They are sorting files that contain detailed medical histories that must not be disclosed.
Story: The line at the register snakes around the corner, and I can feel the tension in the air as customers tap their feet and sigh. My manager’s words echo in my mind: “Always smile, always be patient.” The woman in front of me is red-faced, her voice rising as she complains about a pricing error. I force a smile, trying to soothe her, even as my heart pounds. I know I need to stay calm, to be the friendly face she expects, but my mind keeps drifting to the volunteer shift I just finished. There, I sorted files filled with private medical histories, each one a reminder of the trust placed in me to keep secrets safe. Now, as the customer demands to know why her neighbor got a discount she didn’t, I recognize the name—her neighbor is one of the people whose file I handled earlier. She presses for details, wanting to know more, and I feel the weight of both roles pressing in. I’m expected to be open and helpful here, but I can’t betray the confidentiality I promised. My hands tremble as I search for the right words, caught between two worlds that suddenly feel impossibly far apart.
